author: gorankor
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------
1. Create a test PowerShell script on CentOS 7.3, say "/tmp/test.ps1", obviously change computer name, username and password:

```
$cname = "...";
$UserName = "...";
$PlainPassword = "...";
$Password = $PlainPassword | ConvertTo-SecureString -AsPlainText -Force;
$Credential = New-Object -TypeName System.Management.Automation.PSCredential -ArgumentList $UserName , $Password;
$s = New-PSSession -ComputerName $cname -Credential $Credential -Authentication Negotiate;
if ($s) {
    invoke-command -session $s { Get-Date };
    Remove-PSSession $s;
}
```
2. Run
```
powerShell /tmp/test.ps1
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
It should be able to connect to a remote computer and run the cmdlet.

Actual behavior
---------------
It reports an error:

```
New-PSSession : [...] Connecting to remote server
... failed with the following error message : Could not
start request For more information, see the about_Remote_Troubleshooting Help
topic.
At /tmp/test.ps1:6 char:6
+ $s = New-PSSession -ComputerName $cname -Credential $Credential -Auth ...
+      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : OpenError: (System.Manageme....RemoteRunspace:Re
   moteRunspace) [New-PSSession], PSRemotingTransportException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : 1,PSSessionOpenFailed
```

Environment data
----------------
```
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha
PSEdition                      Core
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.17
CLRVersion
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

Workaround
----------------
I was curious what is going on so I looked at strace output and noticed this:

```
13419 open("/opt/microsoft/powershell/6.0.0-alpha.17/libgssapi_krb5.so", O_RDONLY|O_CLOEXEC) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
13419 open("/etc/ld.so.cache", O_RDONLY|O_CLOEXEC) = 174
13419 fstat(174, {st_mode=S_IFREG|0644, st_size=31133, ...}) = 0
13419 mmap(NULL, 31133, PROT_READ, MAP_PRIVATE, 174, 0) = 0x7f6b562ab000
13419 close(174)                        = 0
13419 open("/lib64/tls/libgssapi_krb5.so", O_RDONLY|O_CLOEXEC) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
13419 open("/lib64/libgssapi_krb5.so", O_RDONLY|O_CLOEXEC) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
13419 open("/usr/lib64/tls/libgssapi_krb5.so", O_RDONLY|O_CLOEXEC) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
13419 open("/usr/lib64/libgssapi_krb5.so", O_RDONLY|O_CLOEXEC) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)

> $ cd /usr/lib64
> $ ls libgssapi_krb5*
> libgssapi_krb5.so.2  libgssapi_krb5.so.2.2
> 
```
So there's no such file there by default. It works if we create it:

`cd /usr/lib64 && ln -s libgssapi_krb5.so.2.2 libgssapi_krb5.so`

Ideally this should work without manual steps needed.

comments.author: giordyb
comments.body:
@gorankor I got it to work on centos by installing the following dependencies

epel-release
krb5-workstation
krb5-devel
gssntlmssp (requires epel-release to be installed beforehand)

comments.author: gorankor
comments.body: @giordyb Sure, I noticed your post, but it's unusual that an application would require "-devel" package like this. I have _krb5-workstation_ and _gssntlmssp_ installed too, but not _krb5-devel_.

comments.author: giordyb
comments.body:
@gorankor I have been trying to get Negotiate to work with powershell on linux for the past few weeks and after numerous installs I managed to get it to work only after installing krb5-devel.

I haven't really investigated on WHY it works (the only difference that I could tell was that the symlink to libgssapi_krb5.so got created) , but I agree with you, it should NOT be required.
You can try it yourself: 

- install krb-devel
- either reboot or run ldconfig
- try to connect

you will also see that if you remove the krb5-devel package you won't be able to connect anymore using the negotiate protocol.

Additional followup:

I'm finding on CentOS 7.5, I need to install the following to enable NTLM:

epel-release
krb5-workstation
gssntlmssp (requires epel-release to be installed beforehand)

Note that NTLM_USER_FILE is not needed nor is krb5-devel.
